Sexual Violence and Sport: An Interview with Franki Riley

27/04/2023

Orla McAndrew (she/her) spoke to Franki Riley about Roses's charity partner Survive and how Roses is helping to tackle sexual violence in sport

Image by Amy Shamblen Hire

By Orla McAndrew

TW: This article will content references to sexual assault and violence.

This year Roses will be shining a light on sexual violence within sports. Sexual violence is different from domestic abuse, and defined as there is no legal definition for domestic abuse as it is so hard to define. Sexual violence is any kind of sexual activity or act that took place without consent.

Roses is partnering with local charity Survive, who work within the community to provide support for victims of sexual violence. Throughout Roses weekend you will be able to donate to Survive, and find out more about the work they do.

Unfortunately, sexual violence is prevelant within the sporting world, from the high profile case regarding Larry Nassar and the USA gymnastics team, to cases within national and regional games, something needs to be done. Through partnering with Survive, Roses is signalling that it supports and will help this change happen.

I spoke to Franki Riley to find out more about what will be going on throughout the Roses weekend.

Why did you decide on the â€˜Shine a Lightâ€™ theme for this year's Roses?

Sexual Violence in sport is a hugely important, and largely unreported, issue. It is not something that has ever been the focus of a major event like this at York before, and I really wanted to change this and start a conversation about how we can all work together to create an environment where sexual violence will not be tolerated. I have my own personal experience with sexual violence in sport, that I recently shared in a blog post on the YUSU website.

Can you tell me a bit more about the charity partner Survive and why you decided to work with them?

Survive are a local York-based charity who work to support survivors of sexual violence to help rebuild their lives. Survive offers a range of specialist services including counselling, trauma therapy and a helpline. The York Sport Union Committee chose Survive as our partner because of how well they align with what we wanted to achieve with this year's Roses. We really wanted to work with a local service that would greatly benefit from the exposure of this event, and a service that works with adults, as adult safeguarding, particularly within sport, is something that needs to be focused on.

Why do you think itâ€™s important for Roses to highlight the more serious issues around sport and its impact on society?

I have always been a passionate believer that sports can be so much more than just about sport. It is so rare to find an event that brings together so many different people from all walks of life to unite around one shared goal and vision. I feel that events like this should be harnessing that power of unity to promote conversations and create long lasting legacies that will better the world we live in. Many people will simply see sport for what it is - and that is completely fine. However, sometimes delivering messages in a subtle way can bring matters to people's attention in a way they never would have before, and that is what I am trying to do.

Can you tell me a bit more about the art pieces which will be on display and why you decided to use art to â€˜shine a lightâ€™ on sexual violence and sport?

As part of this yearâ€™s Roses tournament, in collaboration with the YUSU 2022-23 Environment and Ethics Officer, we are showcasing two artworks created to promote the message and legacy of â€˜Shine A Lightâ€™. One of these artworks will be interactive across the weekend, encouraging athletes and spectators alike to add their thumbprint to pledge against sexual violence in sport. The end result will hopefully be the Roses 2023 logo made up of all the thumbprints showing a huge standing of solidarity with survivors of sexual violence. The second will feature quotes designed to inspire survivors, to show we stand in solidarity with you. And so, we are reaching out to all survivors of sexual violence to ask if they would like to share an uplifting message through this piece of art with other survivors. If you wish to do so, you can provide your message anonymously through a Google Form at the bottom of my blog post.

I chose to showcase artwork because it fits with the overall aim I was trying to achieve - spreading this message in a way that is both subtle but tangible. Anyone can admire these artworks, but when you link them to the theme of the event and find out the narrative behind them, they tell a very powerful message, shown in a very beautiful way.

What do you hope people will get out of seeing the art?

I hope people will be educated and inspired to help spread the message and take action to build a better environment in sport. I hope people will want to donate to our fundraiser, learn more about sexual violence in sport and how we can tackle it, and for survivors I hope they will feel empowered to be able to share their own stories and maybe even report through official channels. I want survivors to know they are not alone, and that by bringing light to this matter, we can make a huge difference.

Can you tell me a bit more about the community afternoon - how can people get involved?

The Community Afternoon is designed to be a key fundraising hub and to bring local community groups to campus to inspire our students to get involved, and to attract members of the local community to see our students in action at Roses. This year we have City of York Hockey joining us alongside the York R.I and their Templars Team - York's inclusive rugby team, with interactive stalls showcasing their teams and sport. We also have a number of fundraising activities happening - think rodeo bulls, a surf simulator, inflatable bowling, face painting and so much more!! The Community Afternoon is taking place on Saturday 29th April between 12-4pm in the James Marquee outside the Psychology Building.

How can people donate to Survive over the weekend?

The simplest way for people to donate to Survive is to visit our Roses 2023 JustGiving Page, but there are also a number of other ways to contribute across the weeknd. We will be selling a range of Roses 2023 merch items including stickers and pin badges all to raise money, and a number of fundraising activities taking place across the weekend. People can also choose to donate an extra 10p to every purchase they make through our YUSU food and drinks outlets across the weekend. Additionally, there will also be a reusable cup refund scheme in operation - and if people return their cups at the end of the weekend, they choose instead for their deposit to be donated to Survive instead.

Have you been doing any other work to raise awareness for sexual violence in sport?

Earlier in the year, during Sexual Violence Awarenss Week, I worked closely with the Sexual Violence Liaison Officers (SVLOs) to put on a number of sports related events, the first time this has been done. I held a screening of the Netflix documentary film Athlete A, that tells the story of the survivors of the USA Gymnastics scandal and recounts their pursuit of justice. We also organised a York Sport Union wide cross-campus relay involving our sports clubs - sending the message that 'It's All Our Responsibility' to be creating a safe environment within sports.

We've also been doing a lot of work to upskill our sports members and leaders. Again in collaboration with the SVLOs, we have delivered Bystander Intervention training to around one third of our sports clubs so far, and this is something I hope will continue every year.

How would you like this conversation to continue after Roses?

I absolutely do not want this message to end when Roses 2023 comes to a close. I have already started planning a project that will be aiming to make the university/college/YUSU reporting processes more easily accessible and transparent to sports clubs and members. It's very ambitious, but I'm hoping this event will give us a bit of a platform to try and influence change at a greater scale than just in York too. I hope that people will feel empowered to continue spreading this message and taking action, and I hope more survivors will feel able to report and speak openly about what they have experienced.

Even if you think sport isn't for you, Roses 2023 is not to be missed! This year's event in particular represents something so important to so many people and every player, supporter, family member, friend that comes to visit is a huge part of spreading this message. Come and get involved and see what it's all about - you won't regret it!
